Half-Life 2. The video game that started the modern generation on first-person shooters and revamped the gaming history into a new era. Originally released in November 2004, the game won multiple game of the year awards and branched gameplay mechanics, including physics and the state-of-the-art game engine that look realistic during its release date. Many people are aware on the game’s popularity and everlasting legacy including various jokes on the awaiting sequel (for many years), but the question remains: Why is this game popular?  The game takes place after the events from Half-Life. You play as Gordon Freeman, the silent protagonist who got a Ph.D. on theoretical physics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) and knows how to use weapons very effectively; a strange paradox for a character with such features yet highly popular and well-recognized. You are sent to City 17 by the G-Man, a mysterious person or a phenomenon with a mysterious and ambiguous agenda, to overthrow Wallace Breen and the alien oppressors, the Combine. The setting and lore in the Half-Life universe is simply the best, taking some influence from George Orwell’s 1984 or other famous dystopian novels to set the story in tone. Gordon’s influence and previous actions will spark oppressed citizens in City 17 to take arms and revolt against the Combine. From City 17 to the prison at Nova Prospekt, each setting is unique, bleak, but beautifully designed, the game simply defined what a video game should be.   Each NPCs and major characters such as Doctor Issac Kleiner, Barney Calhoun, and other characters interact realistically among each other and to you. In regards to Alyx Vance, your ally and companion, Valve spawned the concept of AI teammates and became a true asset in your journey to rally up the oppressed citizens. Besides good character developments, the best attribute for Half-Life 2 was physic interactions and the game engine. The game engine is Source, which feature high-dynamic range rendering, facial animations, and “realistic physics”; the first game that had such a feature like this.   Are there criticisms for the game? I believe so, but to be honest, I couldn’t find any legitimate criticisms for the game. If one criticism has to be addressed, then the problem is the loading sections. Yes, those tedious loading that interrupted the “flow” in the middle of a long level or after finishing a series of firefights against Civil Protection or Combine forces. These loading or “checkpoints” really halt the immersion in the game. However, this is very common on all Half-Life games and I hope that Valve would address this (if they are working on the sequel…).   Half-Life 2 is pure gold, shining flawlessly on the test of time. With great graphical fidelity at its time, voice acting and realistic AI interaction from your allies and enemies, this game is a rare exception of genuine perfection and grand role model for other game developers to pursue their own game designs. The only thing Half-Life 2 (and its episodes) is a full fledge sequel. Besides many jokes, anxieties, and waning patience for Valve to announce the sequel, the game should be in every PC gamer’s Steam library. No exception. Half-Life 2 is simply the best; a grand overture that started and defined the modern gaming industry in the present time.

The plot: Gordon Freeman is brought out of stasis by the G-Man,who inserts him in a train arriving at the fictitous City 17,which was taken over by Combine forces. He eludes the Combine forces and meets Alyx and Barney,and joins the Lambda Resistance. He gets to Dr. Kleiner's lab and assists them in attempting to get a teleporter to teleport him and Alyx to Dr. Eli Vance's lab. The teleportation fails,and he goes through City 17 on foot to get to Eli's lab. He arrives at Black Mesa East and meets up with Eli, where he is captured and taken to a combine prison,Nova Prospekt. Gordon goes through a zombie infested town named Ravenholm and is given a Dune Buggy,which he uses to travel to Nova Prospekt. Eli,Alyx,and Gordon escape,the combine teleporter they used exploding in the process. Gordon and Alyx learn they were in a 'slow teleport'during which a week has passed. Alyx is captured by the Combine and taken to the Citadel,with Gordon,aided by Barney and D0g,goes to the Citadel. He gets caught in a Combine'confiscation chamber',which destroys all of his weapons except for the Gravity Gun,the energy enhancing it's capabilities and turning it into a superior weapon. He is captured riding in a Combine transport pod and is taken to Dr. Breen's office,where he is holding Eli and Alyx captive. Breen explains his plans for further conquest of the humans by the Combine. Breen tries to escape through a portal,but Gordon destroys the portal reactor with the super-charged Gravity Gun. Breen is annihilated in the resulting explosion,but just before Gordon and Alyx get killed,time is frozen,and the G-Man appears,praising Gordon for his actions in City 17 and the Citadel,and puts Gordon back into stasis. Half-Life 2 (stylized as HλLF-LIFE2) is a first-person shooter video game and the sequel to Half-Life (1998). Developed by Valve Corporation, it was released on November 16, 2004, following a five-year $40 million development, during which a substantial part of the project was leaked and distributed on the Internet. The game was developed alongside Valve's Steam software. It introduced the Source game engine and, because of Steam, was the first single-player video game to require online product activation.  Some years after the events of Half-Life, protagonist Gordon Freeman is woken by the enigmatic G-Man to find the world has been taken over by the alien Combine. Joined by allies including resistance fighter Alyx Vance, Gordon searches for a way to free humanity using a variety of weapons, including the object-manipulating gravity gun.  Like its predecessor, Half-Life 2 received critical acclaim. It was praised for its advanced physics, animation, sound, AI, graphics, and narrative. The game won 39 'Game of the Year' awards and the title of 'Game Of The Decade' at the 2012 Spike Video Game Awards, and is widely considered to be one of the greatest and most important video games of all time. Over 6.5 million copies of Half-Life 2 were sold at retail by December 3, 2008, (not including Steam sales); as of February 9, 2011, Half-Life 2 had sold over 12 million copies. Like its predecessor, Half-Life 2 is a single-player first-person shooter broken into several chapters, permanently casting the player as the protagonist Gordon Freeman. The sequel has nearly the same mechanics as Half-Life, including health-and-weapon systems and periodic physics puzzles, except with the newer Source Engine and improved graphics. The player also starts without items, slowly building up an arsenal over the course of the game. Despite the game's mainly linear nature, much effort was put into making exploration rewarding and interesting; many optional areas can be missed or avoided.  A diverse set of enemies is present, which usually require being approached with different tactics: some coordinate in groups to out-maneuver or out-position the player; others, like the Manhack, fly directly at the player through small openings and tight corridors; still others use predictable but powerful attacks, while others hide before swiftly attacking the player. Gordon can kill most enemies with his weapons, or make use of indirect means, exploiting environmental hazards such as explosive pressurized canisters, gas fires or improvised traps. For some portions of the game, Gordon can be joined by up to four armed Resistance soldiers and medics, and can send his team further from him or call them back.  Many of the game's new features utilize its detailed physics simulation. Two sections of the game involve driving vehicles. Instead of button-based puzzles from Half-Life, environmental puzzles are also introduced with makeshift mechanical systems, revolving around the player's new ability to pick up, move, and place objects. Solutions involve objects' physical properties, such as shape, weight, and buoyancy. For example, in Chapter 3, Route Kanal, the player is required to stack cinder blocks on a makeshift see-saw ramp to proceed over a wall. Alternatively, the player can use these to build a crude staircase, so sometimes, multiple approaches lead to the desired outcome.  Part-way through the game, Gordon acquires the Gravity Gun, which allows him to draw distant objects towards himself or forcefully push them away, as well as the ability to manipulate larger and heavier objects that he cannot manipulate without the weapon. These abilities are required to solve puzzles later in the game, and can also be used to great effect in combat, as any non-static object within proximity to the player has the potential to be used as a makeshift defense (e.g. a file cabinet) or a deadly projectile (e.g. a gasoline can or a buzzsaw blade).  The game never separates the player with pre-rendered cutscenes or events; the story proceeds via exposition from other characters and in-world events, and ensures that the player controls Gordon for the entirety of the game. Much of the backstory to the game is simply alluded to, or told through the environment.Half-Life 2 presents a dystopian alternate history of Earth, where the resources of the planet, including the human race itself, are being harvested by an oppressive multidimensional empire, known as the Combine. The game is set around the fictitious City 17, roughly 20 years after the events of its predecessor Half-Life.  During Half-Life, the scientists, including Gordon Freeman, at the Black Mesa Research Facility, accidentally caused an inter-dimensional instability known as a resonance cascade and later as the 'Black Mesa Incident', when an experiment on an alien crystal sample went wrong.[1] Alien creatures, such as the Vortigaunts and headcrabs, from the borderworld of Xen, flooded into the facility. Gordon fought his way through them and the government cover-up response combat units, making it to the Facility's Lambda Complex. There, the Lambda scientists helped Gordon teleport to Xen, where Gordon destroyed a large alien entity keeping the rift open. Gordon was then suddenly extracted by the mysterious G-Man, who had been watching Gordon over the course of the game. Impressed with his ability to survive against all odds, the G-Man offered him a job before placing him into stasis, which Gordon had no option but to accept.  Some time after the ending of Half-Life, the instability at Black Mesa had attracted the attention of the Combine empire, and they invaded Earth. Humanity surrendered at the conclusion of the resulting 'Seven Hour War'. City 17 became the home of the gigantic Combine Citadel, and Dr. Wallace Breen, the Administrator of Black Mesa who had negotiated the surrender, was appointed representative and Administrator to supervise the survivors on behalf of the Combine.[2] Unable to breed due to a Combine suppression field, humanity matured. The Combine implemented a brutal police state of Civil Protection officers and Overwatch soldiers by recruiting and biologically assimilating humans and other species. Meanwhile, an underground 'Lambda Resistance' of humans and Vortigaunts, now working together, was formed. This saw Freeman as a saviour who would lead them to freedom.20 years after the Resonance Cascade, the Combine emerge from the portal with advanced technologies, enabling them to conquer the world in 7 hours. Gordon Freeman is brought out of stasis by the G-Man, who inserts him into a train arriving at City 17.[3] After arriving at the station and eluding Combine forces, Gordon joins Lambda resistance members including Barney Calhoun, a former Black Mesa security guard now working undercover as a Combine CP officer, and Alyx Vance, the daughter of one of Gordon's former colleagues, Dr. Eli Vance. After a failed attempt to teleport to Eli's resistance base known as Black Mesa East from Dr. Kleiner's makeshift laboratory in City 17, Gordon, re-equipped with the HEV suit and a crowbar, is forced to progress on foot through the city's old canal system. After obtaining an airboat, he battles his way to Black Mesa East, several miles from the city.[4][5]  Gordon is reintroduced to Eli and meets another resistance scientist, Dr. Judith Mossman.[6] Alyx introduces Gordon to her pet robot D0g and gives him a 'gravity gun', an instrument which allows Gordon to easily pick up and move large objects. Black Mesa East comes under Combine attack, and Eli and Mossman are taken to a Combine prison, Nova Prospekt. Separated from Alyx, Gordon takes a detour through the zombie-infested town of Ravenholm with help from its last survivor, Father Grigori. After making his way through the town and a mine, Gordon arrives at a Resistance outpost. He uses a customized dune buggy to travel across a crumbling coastal road to Nova Prospekt.

While some of the creatures we encountered in the first episode return in Half Life 2 you mainly fight against humanoid-like creatures. It's a nice touch and it also showcases the artificial intelligence which is also superb in the game.  There are varied environments in the game and there are two things that keep you interested throughout your progress: occasionally you can hop into a vehicle and drive to your next destination. Early on you cannot access this car but you can use a boat to go through a sewers-like stage. The second - and probably best - feature of the game is the Gravity Gun. A gun that does not have ammunition and requires objects - objects in your surroundings that you can pick up and launch at your enemies. There is a level specifically designed for this weapon; a level where ammo is a scarcity and you rely on the precision-aiming skill with the gravity gun.  Single-player campaign offers a long (10-15 hour) experience and the game has two expansion packs (the two provide you with roughly 8-9 hours gameplay time). While Episode 1 is a bit of a letdown Episode 2 is an excellent expansion pack.  I wish Valve concluded the story of Gordon Freeman with releasing a final episode (Episode 3) or a 3rd sequel. I believe this request - coming from not just me but from the community - is well justified.

Quick Summary: An experience worth having. A foundation for all FPS to follow. Must play for everyone.  Longer Review: A great milestone in the progression of First Person Shooters. Gameplay is intuitive in the controls, navigation through from start to finish, audio and visual hints. The dificulty, pace and scale progression are fantastic and make for great replayability. While all this may seem standard in any modern FPS, this is where it was originally mastered. Story is huge in this game. It follows on from the original, Half-Life, set in a future after the events of the original game advanced from the on-site effects to a global change. You are the central character in potentially fixing the situation. The techniques used to tell the story are all through observation. Your only input is with your weapon or to prompt the action of a device or NPC. Exploring or speed running through the game, it's an experience with a lot of depth. Graphically this game has aged, though it was ground breaking when it was released. The model rigging and animation was beyond anything else for real-time rendering. Now, it's less detailed but still better executed than most games on the market. The visuals in this may cause mild headaches at points, but that's probably because you're still playing after 10hrs without grabbing a drink.

Half-Life 2 is a piece of gaming history, much like its predecessor. When it arrived on the scene in 2004, it pushed PC gaming--and first-person shooters, in general--forward by leaps and bounds. It told a story with characters that were endearing through moments of action, horror, poignant exploration, and clever puzzle-solving. The game never takes the player out of the world--cutscenes don't exist in this series. Everything is viewed through your eyes in real time. Gordon Freeman is not a character; Gordon Freeman is the player.  This feature, among others, keeps the player grounded in the world of Half-Life. This makes the battles more real, the exploration more intriguing and poetic as the human stories around you are told by the people and the environments you encounter. Visually, the game is stylistic yet grounded in reality. It is science-fiction, after all. The facial animations are one of the shining moments of the game, despite other technical aspects showing their age. The sounds make you feel like you're in this defeated but hopeful world. The controls are fluid and intuitive.  All in all, the game is still fun to play after ten years, still looks and sounds good, and still has a few features that pull ahead of some contemporary games. Old fans feel right at home with Half-Life 2, new fans will find something interesting to dive into. I recommend new fans try to play in the frame of mind of PC gaming circa 2004, but even without a bit of mental time-travel, the game holds up well enough. Love it or hate it, PC gamers owe it to themselves to experience this milestone in history.

This review does not contain any spoilers - as far as I'm aware...   I've just completed Half-Life 2 and find there is so much to say about this, it would be impossible to do it within the amount of time I'm wanting to spend writing this review, and so I'll make a short..ish review - or I'll try to anyway.   This game is very interesting, for it was made years ago and contains so much... thought and creativity. I must admit, through the first half of the game, I was becoming bored. It just seemed as though I was doing the same thing all the time. However, one thing I did pick up was the puzzles. There were some puzzles that got me confused during the first half of the game, and I find that to be a very creative thing to add in to this kind of game. It has a sci-fi element, and when puzzles and sci-fi are put together, it really does create an amazing experience.   During the second half of the game, I found I was starting to enjoy the game more. I'd began to rush through the game due to it's massive story line. By rushing, I mean I sprinted and jumped and just full-out went in shooting enemies and picking up those health kits ASAP. It really was a big help and I died a lot less - believe it or not.   New enemies were introduced in the second half and I found it really cool about 3/4 into the game where something special about one of the enemies had came up. I won't say any more due to the fact that I don't want to give spoilers.   At the end of the game, I felt amazed. The last level really was something, and it was totally worth the wait, as I had been told by a couple of people that have played the game before me. Everything they said was true. The last level really is worth the countless hours of gameplay to get there, and the main enemy behind all of the... chaos... was amazing.  The ending made me a little bit confused - but I think that was supposed to happen. You can find out for yourself when you play the game. ;)  During the game, there are a lot of conversations that you have to stand and listen to (or ignore) before you can continue the level. This was very fraustrating for me, and you may fidn it fraustrating as well. A couple of friends have told me that it was also very fraustrating for them, too.  Overall, I'd say this game really was a big step towards the new games that are produced now. All of it's creativity seems to have been expanded into lots of AAA games out there right now and improved. I'd rate this game 7/10 due to it being a little bit long-winded - but trust me, it's totally worth it. Also I deducted another point due to the un-skippable conversations that you have to go through.  Also, there is a free update for the graphics. I have not used it for my gameplay experience, but you, personally, might like some better graphics. So go on the Steam Store and get 'Half-Life 2: Update' for free once you have bought the main game. :)

Half-Life 2 is extremely well-made and passionately executed. So often the game makes you chuckle in disbelief, press the 'F9' (load last save) key because you feel you *must* see that breathtaking sequence again and in overall it makes you replay it time and time again. This game is, in simple words, an astounding accomplishment.   Exceptionally well thought-out storyline and immersive experience; we see everything from Gordon's eyes. Half-Life is unique in the sense that you are not the intended game's protagonist, the game's protagonist is YOU. Everything is left up to your own interpretation, understanding and words. There's so much to say about the saga of Half-Life (because yes, the Episodes as well as the first game and its two expansions, OF and BS, are just as fantastic), but words are weak to convey justice to such a magnificent game. In my opinion, it is simply the best first-person shooter of all time. The most well thought-out and influential, at least. Even though the typical 'dystopia-alien invasion' storyline is quite common these days, Valve found a way to make it unique. I believe what makes Half-Life stand out from everything else is that Valve grabbed a storyline which is now common and sometimes hackneyed and made it BELIEVABLE. They made it feel REALISTIC and BELIEVABLE to the player, and crafted a wonderful, unusual protagonist which was given somewhat of a story but the rest is filled by you; this protagonist makes this absurd world of aliens, torture, blood, fear and dystopia work, no matter how unrealistic it may seem.  Half-Life, the entire franchise, has haunted me for a long time. The story is as rich and big in complexity as it is in enigma, so many questions are conveyed and yet left unanswered. I love the game, I'm in complete love with Gordon Freeman and the other characters (specially Barney) and with how well all the chapters in this game were made. Ravenholm is capable to fetch a perception of sadness and fear, the rebellion and the uprising elude feelings of both hope and doom, questions of *what* is going to happen arise and more disappointment appears because there are *no* definite answers, at all. Valve keeps throwing stuff at you and you don't ever have enough time to process it. And when you sit down to think about it, too many answers are possible. Valve takes the whole 'open to interpretation' notion at a whole new level.  I'd recommend this game to everyone, and if you don't have this game in your Steam library, I'M JUDGING YOU REAL HARD HERE. No, but it's a must-play, even if it isn't your type of game. Even with how exceptional the game is, however, many people may not and do not enjoy it, not only because it might not be 'their cup of tea', but because Half-Life 2 is a game which requires patience (not as much as the first, though!), and it may not be a good game to someone who plays games to slouch or relax a bit, or to play for a short while. It's pretty intense and hectic. However, I'd still recommend it nonetheless.   Half-Life 2 gets a 10 out of 5 from me!

The graphics and level-design are both very aesthetically pleasing, and the actors all do their job very well (Though the best voice actor would definitely have to be Dr. Freeman's. Honestly, I only have two very small qualms with this game and that would be the loading screens and occaisional glitches. I never found an actual in-game glitch in graphics or animation, but rarely the sound would cut out of a random NPC's dialogue. And for a game that flows so well, the loading screen for the next section of a level can bring all that build-up to a halt. But these are only minor problems, that didn't take away all that much from how great the game is. Half-Life 2 is definitely one of the best video games I've ever played, and I can guarantee it'll be one of the best games you'll ever play as well. I cannot recommend this game enough.

Half-Life 2 is a science fiction first person shooter developed by Valve Software of the Source Engine. Set in the dystopian 'City 17,' physicist gone action hero: Gordon Freeman is tasked with stopping human ambassador Dr. Wallace Breen from doing something evil probably. Who can honestly say in today's economy?  Half-Life 2 is a game that I would only really call good enough. It's clear that the form of story-telling and gameplay the game uses was pretty out of the norm at the time of it's release, but when it's played in retrospect it can feel a little cluttered and unproffesional at times.  I'll be fair to Half-Life, it's not IT'S fault that it was so influential. And it's probably worth at least a little bit of limelight considering that it managed to fit so much innovation in such a bizzare sequel, but if you ignore the enemy AI, real time facial animation, half decent physics system, and that plot twist that you defintely saw coming, than all you have is a broken shooter with the plot of a semi-decent teen dystopia novel.  The combat itself isn't terrible it's the scenarios the game bats you with that are the crux of the problem. It is objectivley unsatisfying to be slowly staggering your way to a gun turret/sniper by dodging between cover. It is objectively not fun to use the rocket launcher on a helicopter that shoots you the moment you try to properly aim. It is BAD game design to distract the player with enemies when they are supposed to be focusing on something tactical instead of action based.  The level design is bland and unfocused, without a lot of setpeices that stray from the very basic visual aspect of fun. And although the actual designs of enemies and structures are interesting and dynamic, they do a poor job at guiding the player through them towards the goal. There were too many times when I simply got lost in the same couple looping rooms, not realizing there was an entire other segment hidden behind a ledge somewhere. If I can't progress in a video game, want it to be because I was too inadequate to follow it's orders, not because the video game did a poor job at ordering me in the firt place.  There are too many gimmicks that stray on for far too long. Instances where I say to myself, 'Sure it would be cool to [Traverse the mechanisms under a bridge] [Fight a helicopter that spews bombs in a motorized boat] [Command a squad of allies through dangerous terrain]' but I ended up being sick of it by the time I met the halfway mark of that gimmick alone. And that's not including the gimmicks that DIDN'T seem like fun ideas. (I'm looking at you Ant Lions, Head-Crab Mine, and driving section!)  None of what I said is meant to imply that Half-Life 2 is a terrible game, heck it's not even a BAD game, it's a good game, maybe even a great game, but it definetly isn't a perfect game. It has it's fair share of entertaining fights, sure. And even some gripping bits of story near the end. (Heck the entirety of the climax is the most fun I've genuinely had in this game.) But that doesn't mean that praising the game with perfect scores is going to make Valve any better at video game design. And heck, it isn't going to make Half-Life 3 any better. And let's be honest, if THAT game doesn't end up being perfect...  ... ... ... ..Naw we'll probably still love Gaben

Half-Life 2 is a nice little FPS game that lets you think outside the box when it comes to gameplay. The game was a big deal when it was released, being the successor to the original Half-Life, which was just as critically acclaimed as the sequel.  GAMEPLAY (8/10) Half-Life 2, like I said earlier, really lets you think outside the box. It's one of the few games that integrates the physics engine into the gameplay. You can use your 'gravity gun' to hurl projectiles at the bad guys, or use physics objects to aid you in the gameplay, like quickly scrabbling together a makeshift barricade from barrels and wooden palletes. The gunplay has aged a bit - Half-Life 2 doesn't have a cover system, leaning system (really wish it had this), iron sights, steady aim feature, or many of the things that are common in modern titles. The game was fairly classic-styled even at the time in this way. Sometimes, the classic style serves the game well - other times, it just makes it not as up to par to games of today.  PRESENTATION (9/10) Half-Life 2 is great in this aspect, especially for its time. The game has really great music that gets you pumped up for action. The graphics looked pretty good for 2004. The characters look extremely realistic and have really great animations, too - something that was revolutionary when Half-Life 2 came out. The voice actors are pretty good and deliver lines believably and with emotion.  STORY (9/10) The game has a unique storytelling method. It rarely reveals detail directly. However, that does not make the story have any less depth. The developers left around many clues that leave you guessing and speculating about the backstory. Put all the clues together and you have a really well-crafted backstory. The game has an interesting cyberpunk, dystopian setting with believable characters. The main plotline is good and fairly realistic. Control is never taken from the player, except times where it makes sense - That's right, they don't interrupt the gameplay with cutscenes.  Good game. If you haven't played it already, it's considered a classic. If you have ever enjoyed a FPS, you'll like this one.

Half-Life 2... I wanted to get this review out of my system for a very long time. Back in 2004 when this game was released, I got hooked. It was another game changer, it paved the road for fps games to come, and it made history with it's many aspects that still hold up to this day... or do they? Looking at it now, Half-Life 2 is one of those games that has aged a lot since it's release 11 years ago. I think it's safe to say that in some aspects it's aged well, but in others... well we'll get onto that very soon.  Gameplay in Half-Life 2 is relatively slow, with your standard pace of walking. This sets the pace of the game itself, where you're mostly walking down your path fighting your enemies. I think this slower pacing helps the game, by letting the player appreciate it's atmosphere and visuals more. However I must admit that the visuals don't have the power they did back in 2004. They can't hold the player's attention as well as they did. The game could've made up for this by also focusing on it's ambient atmosphere. Most of the time it gets that right, but there's times where I felt that certain areas lacked atmosphere to them. Gameplay has a certain variety to it, that I think most games lack even today, and this is a plus. Valve is very well aware that a game needs to alternate between it's gameplay styles for it to remain fresh for the player. You have sections with platforming, exploration, high intensity combat, sneaking, physics puzzles, and driving. Most of the time, the game does a decent job in keeping this variety up well. However there's times where it fails to do so, and you get drawn out sections like the coastal levels. It is here that Valve's focus on the physics sensation of the 2004's really drags the game down. Had this chapter had more variety, and less focus on 'look, we have driveable vehicles', it wouldn't have dragged the game down so much. The same could be said about the boat riding segment, but the problem there was less prominent. Back in the day, these problems were less prominent, because the sights, the expanses and the physics really tied your attention down, but today, that part of the magic is gone.  Story-wise, this game improves upon it's pedecessor's storytelling by bringing in unique characters, who are all interesting for the most part, and the developers obviously focused a lot on the depth of the story. I must admit, my favorite part of the game were the Breencasts, which showed an obvious devotion to a certain philosophy behind the propaganda spread around by Breen and his overlords. It had spirit to it. I just wish such a focus was given to other aspects of the story. This is where I'm gonna go onto the negatives. The problem with the characters, is that their introduction comes out of nowhere. We're to assume we knew a lot of our characters before, like Eli, Kleiner, Barney, who were all just stock models back in the original. I think if the game actually built new characters from the ground up, it would have benefited the game more. In this game, Alyx was a more interesting and well made character than in the subsequent games. She wasn't as clingy, she knew her way around and could operate alone. Her time with Gordon was minimal, and there wasn't the uncanny romantic tension between her and the player as there was in the episodes. She was bearable.  Still, I think one of the things that hurt the story the most were it's shortcomings from the original game. Gordon Freeman was originally a silent protagonist in Half-Life 1, because the role didn't need him to talk. Character interaction was limited to unnamed characters who all sounded the same, and looked alike. There was little to no character development in the original. This however, is no longer the case in Half-Life 2, here characters directly interact with the player on a personal level, and it's so obvious that Valve tried their best to form the dialouge around the silent protagonist concept, and it falls short. Without Gordon deciding for us what to do, the player really gets to feel the confines of the linear progression of the game, as he is practically forced to go through everything in the game, to the last detail. Would we at least hear him acknowledge, approve, or decide to do what is ahead of him, it would at least dull the feeling of linearity.  I think this is perfectly apparent when Alyx thanks Gordon at the end for coming after her father and her in the citadel. Gordon, even from the player's perspective, really had no choice in his actions. It feels like he's completely forced to do everything by the rock-solid linearity of the game, without any choice. This really detracts from the immersion of the game.  Valve obviously wanted the player to feel like he's in Gordon's shoes. The game's ego-pleasuring way of revering Gordon Freeman, who is really the player in this case adds to this aspect. I found that this also detracted from my suspension of disbelief, because in the original game Gordon Freeman was just an everyman facing hostile aliens and military with no training behind him. He was just another survivor trying to get out alive. Half-Life 2 abandons this, and turns the player into an object of worship. Gordon is no longer an everyman, he's no longer the average joe who's just trying to stay alive. He's a legend, he's a savior, a messiah. I find that this distanced me from Gordon, because I can't immerse myself into that role. At the same time Valve wants me to feel like I am a hero, since Gordon is supposed to be me. There's a major conflict here arising from the silent protagonist concept, and it's datedness shows in this game a lot.  The ending in this game has been criticized a lot by many, but I think it's the least of the game's problems. The game cuts out after we've defeated our true enemy, Dr. Breen. We've disabled the citadel's portal, we've defeated Breen, and the Combine are falling around us. We're saved from an explosion at the last momment by the G-Man. I think that the ending, in a way, was very well done. It marked the end of the human effort by Gordon Freeman, the momment where the great savior, the hero meets his end against something he triggered unwantingly. His journey would've been over, had it not been for the G-Man. It was a kind of poetic seal, because had he not been saved, he would've died instantly. His life in that line of events was over, and I think that at this point, a sequel might not have been necessary at all. The series could've ended here. The G-Man's words also provided an epilouge to the game that I felt closed it in a way that fit with Half-Life.  Overall, I think Half-Life 2 hasn't aged as well as other games have. Time has withered it's edges, when it comes to the original awe and freshness of it's engine that amazed us all back in 2004. Still, does that mean it's a bad game? Not at all, it still holds up in many aspects. I recommend it, because it's a piece of gaming history, and overall it still has the spirit that made it really good.

Half-Life 2 had all I really needed to continue on after the highly-acclaimed 1998 First-Person Shooter. It featured a form of storytelling that was far more in your face than the original but not too in your face to drive away any fanbase. The music is centered onto events which i though were appropriate for an audial playback however I did have one point in which I felt the music wasn't right, it was close to the start when you re-acquire your suit I had the same problem with Half-Life 1 though, but 1 meh didn't deter me from the game. Half-Life 2's gameplay is quite like the original in a way that includes the same puzzle-inspirations and various other things including a more intense combat experience with a few more guns. The thing that made HL2 stand out at the time was the physics engine which for its time was revolutionary but the physics engine included in this installment is (in my opinion) better than any other physics engine to date (Portal and Garry's Mod include the same physics engine). For example if i take a look at Fallout 4, a game released this year its got nothing on HL2's physics (Gordon Freeman is a theoretical physicist so that is why they added a physics engine (totally not to make money)). All around it was revolutionary in its day and nothing less than enjoyable today.
